quizQuestions.questionText: Which SQL aggregate function calculates the average value of a numeric column?
quizQuestions.explanation: AVG() is the standard SQL function for calculating the arithmetic mean (average) of values in a numeric column, ignoring NULL values.

quizQuestions.questionText: What happens if you use COUNT(column_name) when the column contains NULL values?
options: NULL values are counted as NULL
quizQuestions.explanation: COUNT(column_name) counts only non-NULL values in the specified column. To count all rows including those with NULL values, use COUNT(*).

quizQuestions.questionText: Which clause is used to filter groups in a GROUP BY query?
quizQuestions.explanation: The HAVING clause is specifically designed to filter groups after the GROUP BY operation has been performed, unlike WHERE which filters individual rows before grouping.

quizQuestions.questionText: What is the result of the following query: SELECT MAX(salary) - MIN(salary) FROM employees;
options: The difference between highest and lowest salary
Two separate columns with max and min
This query will produce an error
quizQuestions.correctAnswer: The difference between highest and lowest salary
quizQuestions.explanation: This query calculates the range of salaries by subtracting the minimum salary from the maximum salary. SQL allows arithmetic operations between aggregate functions in the select list.

quizQuestions.questionText: What happens when you use GROUP BY without any aggregate functions?
options: It returns one row for each group
It is equivalent to using DISTINCT
It returns only the first row of each group
quizQuestions.correctAnswer: It returns one row for each group
quizQuestions.explanation: GROUP BY without aggregate functions will return one row for each distinct combination of values in the GROUP BY columns, similar to DISTINCT but with different semantics in some databases.
